text: Vladimir Putin may still order an invasion of Ukraine, as President Biden said yesterday. Putin has long been obsessed with Ukraine, viewing it as part of Russia’s immediate orbit. And more than 150,000 Russian troops remain ready to pour over the border if Putin gives the order.

headline: Florida Woman Used Pandemic-Relief Loan to Pay a Hit Man, Police Say
text: The Paycheck Protection Program is intended to help businesses meet their payroll during the pandemic, but scores of people have faced charges that they used the federal loan money on extravagances like Ferraris, Lamborghinis, jewelry and lavish vacations.

headline: British inflation climbs to 5.5 percent, highest in 30 years.
text: Inflation in Britain accelerated in January, with prices increasing at their fastest pace in three decades, adding to concerns about a painful squeeze on household budgets a day after separate data showed wage growth wasn’t keeping up with prices.

headline: Biden Rejects Trump’s Claim of Privilege for White House Visitor Logs
text: President Biden ordered the National Archives to hand over a range of visitor logs from the Trump White House to the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, rejecting his predecessor’s claim that the material is protected by executive privilege.

headline: Inside a Grand Parisian Building, a Secret Atelier
text: On a quiet stretch of the Rue Saint-Lazare, shielded from the commotion of the nearby Paris train station that shares the street’s name, there’s an ornate 1880s Haussmann-style building with a delicately carved limestone facade. It’s by far the grandest building on this Ninth Arrondissement block — and thus an unexpected home for Saint-Lazare, a product and design firm best known for its utilitarian aesthetic and stylish use of humble materials.

headline: Troubled London Police Force Searches for a New Leader
text: LONDON — London’s police department was already dealing with a crisis of trust amid allegations of misogyny, racism and bullying when it became embroiled in a political drama. Last month, it opened an investigation into parties at Downing Street during lockdown that could determine Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s political fate.

headline: The Ceramists Ushering in a New Era of Surrealism
text: IN HIS 1869 poetic novel, “Les Chants de Maldoror,” the French writer Isidore Lucien Ducasse, known pseudonymously as the Comte de Lautréamont, describes a young boy who is as “beautiful as the chance encounter of a sewing machine and an umbrella on an operating table.” Lautréamont’s book was rediscovered and championed by the Surrealists after World War I, and this particular simile became a kind of foundational mantra for the movement. Its juxtaposition of mundane objects in an unexpected setting conveyed the Surrealists’ cheekiness, their love of the incongruous and irrational and their overriding fascination with found curiosities.

headline: Google Plans Privacy Changes, but Promises to Not Be Disruptive
text: Google said on Wednesday that it was working on privacy measures meant to limit the sharing of data on smartphones running its Android software. But the company promised those changes would not be as disruptive as a similar move by Apple last year.

headline: A Blueprint for Suing Gun Makers Emerges
text: The gun maker Remington yesterday agreed to pay $73 million to settle a lawsuit by families of nine Sandy Hook shooting victims over the AR-15-style rifle used in the 2012 massacre. It’s believed to be the largest such settlement by a gun manufacturer, but it also raises questions about whether these companies will be held accountable in future shootings.

headline: How Long Will Los Angeles Have a Mask Mandate?
text: For almost two years, as the coronavirus has surged and receded and surged again in Los Angeles, Barbara Ferrer, the county’s public health director, has been a steady voice of caution.

headline: The Suit Is Not So Dead After All
text: It was the penultimate night of New York Fashion Week, and Mayor Eric Adams was finally sitting front and center at a major fashion show, his first big one since assuming office. (Earlier in the week he stopped in to see the In the BLK presentation of three emerging Black designers created by the #ChangeFashion initiative.) The designer of choice?

headline: Retail Sales Jumped in January, Another Sign of the Economy’s Resilience
text: Prices were rising fast, products were in short supply and the Omicron variant put a chill on the country at the start of the year. Through it all, American consumers kept spending.

headline: Museum Security Guard Adds Eyes to Painting’s Faceless Figures
text: A security guard who recently vandalized a 1930s-era painting during his first shift at a museum in Russia has been suspended for what a top official at the museum called “a stupid mistake.”

headline: Vincent Zhou, who helped U.S. figure skaters win team silver, finishes his coronavirus isolation period.
text: Vincent Zhou, who helped the U.S. team win silver in the team figure skating event last week, on Tuesday was cleared to return to the Olympics after testing positive for the coronavirus and spending a week in isolation.

headline: A Super Cabin on the Shores of Quadra Island, B.C.
text: This six-acre waterfront property on the southern shore of Quadra Island, off the coast of British Columbia, Canada, is for sale for $4.5 million.

headline: House Hunting in Canada: Seclusion in the Forests of British Columbia
text: This cedar-shingled three-bedroom home occupies nearly six acres on the southern shore of Quadra Island, which sits between Vancouver Island and the Pacific coastline of British Columbia, Canada. The wooded waterfront property, completed in 2004, includes a three-bedroom guest cabin and a jetty with a dock large enough to accommodate a 45-foot boat.

headline: Afghans Find Room for Debate on Twitter Spaces
text: Hundreds listened as the former officials spoke about corruption, waste and theft in the government they once all served. Cabinet ministers, lawmakers and directors threw accusations at former colleagues of stealing public funds while largely absolving themselves.

headline: Shark Kills Swimmer in Rare Death Off Sydney Coast
text: A shark killed a swimmer on Wednesday off the coast of Sydney, Australia, officials said, in what local news outlets called the first fatal shark bite near the city in decades.

headline: On the Edge of a Polish Forest, Where Some of Putin’s Darkest Fears Lurk
text: REDZIKOWO, Poland — Tomasz Czescik, a Polish archaeologist and television journalist, walks his dog each morning through a forest near his home here on NATO’s eastern flank, wandering along the edge of a green chain-link fence topped with razor wire.

headline: British Officer Breaks a Barrier With Solo Trip to the South Pole
text: Isolation has been forced on so many during the coronavirus pandemic. But for Harpreet “Preet” Chandi, a 32-year-old captain in the British Army, it was a choice on the way to a bigger goal.

headline: Doctors Are More Likely to Describe Black Patients as Uncooperative, Studies Find
text: Medical records contain a plethora of information, from a patient’s diagnoses and treatments to marital status to drinking and exercise habits.

headline: Afghans Who Bet on Fast Path to the U.S. Are Facing a Closed Door
text: LOS ANGELES — As a combat interpreter in Afghanistan, Sharif Azizi helped U.S. Special Forces hunt down Taliban targets, even after suffering leg and chest injuries from stepping on a land mine. When his life was threatened by the insurgents, the United States acknowledged his eight years of service and in 2017 brought him to safety in Los Angeles.

headline: How Jonathan Larson Taught Me to Become a Better Critic
text: I watched “Tick, Tick … Boom!,” Netflix’s film adaptation of the Jonathan Larson musical, four and a half times in the span of three weeks. I’ve listened to the soundtrack three times, with the exception of the opening song, “30/90.” That I’ve listened to at least a dozen times.

headline: Irma Thomas, a Soul Queen Far Beyond New Orleans
text: The singer Irma Thomas has long been known as the Soul Queen of New Orleans, a title that feels both richly deserved and far too provincial. Her songs never topped the Billboard pop chart, but they did climb it. And even today, they’re covered by bar bands and in blues jams across the country.

headline: In Pictures: Ukraine holds military drills.
text: Ukraine has sought for weeks to tamp down the language regarding the peril the country finds itself in as Russia amasses forces to its north, south and east. At the same time, the armed forces have been actively preparing to defend the nation. President Volodymyr Zelensky attended military exercises on Wednesday at a base near Rivne, about 60 miles from the Belarus border.

headline: An Olympic tussle over a snowboard logo roils the Games for a U.S. athlete.
text: It wasn’t just Julia Marino’s silver medal performance in the slopestyle event that grabbed attention in Beijing.

headline: ‘My Mother Cannot Help Me Through This’
text: The novelist Sheila Heti puts her diary in alphabetical order to see if she’s changed over the years.

headline: It’s Stew Time (Unless It’s Not)
text: Good morning. We’ve got a whole world of hearty stews and braises waiting for you right now, balms against winter’s bite. Take a look at Yewande Komolafe’s new recipe for eintopf (above), the hearty German stew. She learned to make the dish from her parents, who picked it up when they were graduate students in Berlin, a simple one-pot preparation of braised short ribs with fennel, squash and sweet potato that could provide meals for a week.

headline: ‘Taste’ Review: A Slow, Sensual Hallucination Set in Vietnam
text: I won’t bother explaining what “Taste” is about. It’s more dreamed up than a term like “about” can capture. The movie is all tableaux — pacific, surveillant, surreal. Three naked women ride a motorbike around a tiny room. Those same women arrange a boxy television set on a top bunk while, in an adjoining room, a man pumps himself into a fourth woman. The women drag that man (he’s naked, too) from one room to the next, careful not to wake him as he sleeps with his arms around a swordfish as long as he is. A scene later, the five of them are hacking the fish up, cleaning it, for the meal we later see them eat. Later on: karaoke.

headline: TelevisaUnivision Unveils Plans for Streaming Service in Spanish
text: There are nearly 600 million Spanish speakers in this world, and they have become a highly sought-after audience for streaming services. Netflix announced last year that it would spend $300 million on original Mexican productions. Disney+ said in late 2020 that it had more than 70 original Spanish-language productions in development. WarnerMedia started HBO Max in Latin America in June, announcing a commitment of 100 productions in the region in the next two years. And NBCUniversal’s Telemundo will offer Tplus this fall on Peacock’s premium tier.

headline: Ken Kurson, Kushner Ally Pardoned by Trump, Takes Plea Deal
text: Ken Kurson, a former editor of The New York Observer who was charged with unlawfully spying on his former wife, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to two misdemeanors, with the opportunity to have the charges further reduced after a year.

headline: Mitski, in and Out of the Spotlight
text: “Laurel Hell,” the new album by the beloved indie-rock singer-songwriter Mitski, continues her shift toward a focus on pop — a move that feels somewhat at odds with the general reluctance she displays in almost every other aspect of being a performer.

headline: Long a Foundational Material, Concrete Is Now a Finishing Touch
text: Toward the end of 2019, Natalie Feltham started to look for a simple, minimal vessel for burning incense in her home.

headline: P.J. O’Rourke Wrote With High, Cranky Style in a Shrinking Tradition
text: During the 1980s and ’90s, his heyday, P.J. O’Rourke owned one of those bylines — like Nora Ephron’s, or Michael Kinsley’s, or Calvin Trillin’s — that made many readers, including this one, tingle with anticipation.

headline: Climate Change Anxiety and Therapy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Taking Aim at Environmental Racism, Without Mentioning Race
text: Before we get to the news this week, we wanted to tell you about some changes we’re making to the Climate Fwd: newsletter — changes meant to help make sense of the climate crisis and what it means for you. Starting next month, Climate Fwd: will be delivered twice a week instead of once. And, Somini Sengupta, the Times’s global climate correspondent, will be your new guide to the latest news and ideas as the newsletter’s lead writer. Please stay tuned for more.

headline: Another Kind of Face Mask
text: There’s a lot to see at fashion week. Blink (or scroll too fast) and you’ll miss the details: feathered bags, futuristic sunglasses, fork jewelry. All month long, we’ll spotlight the things we saw that surprised or delighted us.

headline: Congressional Democrats Ask Biden to Review Treatment of Black Migrants
text: WASHINGTON — More than 100 Democratic members of Congress pressed President Biden on Wednesday to address “disparate and often inhumane treatment” of Black migrants by the immigration enforcement system, reviving concerns over the mass deportations last fall of asylum-seeking Haitians despite the ongoing crisis in their country.

headline: It’s Time We Reclaim Our Focus
text: The typical American worker focuses on a given task for just three minutes. Each day, we touch or check our phones more than 2,000 times, and spend more than three hours staring at them, on average. So says Johann Hari, an author who has previously written about depression and addiction, in his new book “Stolen Focus.” It is an investigation into how we got ourselves into this distracted state — what Mr. Hari describes as an “attention crisis.”

headline: Yes, There Were Fashion Week Parties
text: Is it really New York Fashion Week? Many designers sat this one out and, for a moment, the party calendar looked pretty bleak. Luckily, the invitations began trickling in late last week. Here are some highlights from Friday.

headline: Beyond the Statistics in Pedestrian Fatalities
text: Across the U.S. pedestrian deaths have surged during the pandemic. I wanted to understand why.

headline: How Kathy Hochul Went From Unexpected Governor to Clear Front-Runner
text: When Kathy Hochul unexpectedly ascended to the governor’s mansion last August, elevated after her predecessor’s sexual harassment scandal, she hardly resembled the kind of political powerhouse New Yorkers were accustomed to — brash, self-aggrandizing, male and from downstate.

headline: San Francisco Ousts School Board Members
text: Today: San Francisco voters oust school board members. A sexual harassment case at Harvard exposes the messy realities of Title IX complaints. And, some pretty on-the-nose life advice from a kindergartner.

headline: Who built Putin’s long table? Competing claims arise from Spain and Italy.
text: With Ukraine’s fate uncertain, world attention has focused on urgent negotiations, troop movements, threats, high-profile meetings.

headline: Woman Sues Over Death of Child Born in Georgia Jail
text: A woman who went into labor at a jail in Clayton County, Ga., two years ago said the facility’s medical staff and sheriff ignored her pleas to be taken immediately to a hospital and are responsible for the death of her baby, according to a federal lawsuit.

headline: Nope to Metamates, Googlers and Puritans
text: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.

headline: Protesters in Ottawa are on alert after the police order them to disperse.
text: On Rideau Street in downtown Ottawa, after the police handed out leaflets warning protesters to leave or face arrest, a group of them chatted with officers, asking if they planned to follow through.

headline: The Myth of the Magic Sports Beard
text: So you were not crazy about the Super Bowl hero Cooper Kupp’s scraggly, mountain-man whiskers? Neither is his family, apparently.

headline: In the Olympic Bubble, a Small Taste of the Food Finds of China
text: See our coverage of the Winter Olympics Closing Ceremony here.

headline: Beverly Ross, Teenage Songwriter in Rock ’n’ Roll’s Youth, Dies at 87
text: Beverly Ross, who with hits like “Lollipop” became one of the top female songwriters in rock ’n’ roll’s early years, but who ended her career early after a work relationship turned sour, died on Jan. 15 in a hospital in Nashville. She was 87.

headline: Britain will extend Covid vaccine eligibility to all children 5 to 11.
text: British children aged 5 to 11, one of the last remaining groups in the country still broadly ineligible for the coronavirus vaccine, will be offered doses under new guidance announced on Wednesday by Britain’s independent vaccine advisory committee.

headline: Trans Swimmer Revives an Old Debate in Elite Sports: What Defines a Woman?
text: At the Ivy League women’s swimming championships this week, many eyes in the crowd will be fixed on Lia Thomas, a star of the University of Pennsylvania team. In recent months, Thomas has made headlines not only for her speed — handily winning one Ohio race that went viral — but also for her gender identity.

headline: The Little TV Industry That Could
text: Americans who stream a lot of television are likely to have some familiarity with British or South Korean or Latin American TV. They may even have an idea of what to expect from a Turkish or Israeli or South African show.

headline: Review: Afro-Colombian Dancing Reawakens the Joyce Theater
text: The motion is small, a little twisting in the hips. But like a tremor before an earthquake, it signals larger shifts. Soon, drums kick in and dancers explode into percussive action — shaking, undulating, whacking the air with the force of those drums.

headline: NATO plans to shift forces to counter Moscow’s troop buildup around Ukraine.
text: Pointing to the “new normal” of Europe in the face of Russian military provocations, the secretary-general of NATO said on Wednesday the alliance was drawing up plans for new combat units in central and southeastern Europe, while Britain said it was doubling the size of its NATO deployment in Estonia.

headline: Blackstone expands further into rental housing in the United States.
text: The private equity firm Blackstone, the largest owner of commercial real estate in the world, is expanding its portfolio of rental housing and commercial real estate in the United States.

headline: Mamoudou Athie Gets Switched On by TV on the Radio and ‘Cowboy Bebop’
text: Mamoudou Athie speaks unabashedly about tenderness, humanity and humility, and doing the right thing.

headline: Fed officials discussed removing policy support more quickly if inflation continues to accelerate.
text: Officials at the Federal Reserve expressed concern about inflation at their meeting in January, in particular that it had spread beyond pandemic-affected sectors into other areas, and agreed it would be warranted to begin scaling back their support for the economy faster than they previously had anticipated, minutes of the meeting released Wednesday showed.

headline: Can New York Overhaul Its Complex, Antiquated Court System?
text: For decades, governors and lawmakers have unsuccessfully tried to overhaul New York’s antiquated and fragmented court system, considered among the most complex to navigate in the country.

headline: The Real Housewives of Sustainable Fashion
text: The eye doesn’t always know where to settle.

headline: ‘CODA’ Star Troy Kotsur on His Historic, Healing Oscar Nomination
text: It has only been a week since Troy Kotsur became the first deaf man to earn an Oscar nomination for acting, but to the 53-year-old performer, it already feels like the start of something new.

headline: The Rise of Big Tech May Just Be Starting
text: The stock market has lately soured on the technology industry. Stock prices of many of the largest companies are down this year, some slightly — shares of Apple and Google have fallen more than 6 percent — and some stupendously: Facebook's parent company, Meta, and Netflix have lost about a third of their value since the New Year. Because surging tech stocks drove a big part of the stock market’s rise in 2021, their decline has contributed much to the market’s fall. The S & P 500 is down by about 7 percent in 2022.

headline: Organizers call for the protest in Ottawa to become too large for the police to break up.
text: As the authorities threaten to arrest people blocking the streets of the capital, protest organizers on Wednesday appealed to supporters to pour into Ottawa and make their gatherings too large for the police to disperse.

headline: A new Virginia law will end school mask mandates and limit remote instruction.
text: After weeks of back-and-forth, Gov. Glenn Youngkin of Virginia, a Republican, signed into law on Wednesday a bill that will effectively bar mask mandates in schools, by giving parents the right to exempt their children from mask-wearing without stating a reason.

headline: U.S. Warns Americans Abroad Not to Count on a Rescue
text: WASHINGTON — As U.S. officials grew convinced this month that Russia might invade Ukraine, they implored American citizens to leave the country immediately — and added a grim addendum.

headline: Six Highlights From the Black Film Archive
text: Next week, the Black Film Archive — a living register of Black cinema — will officially turn six months old. Its roots, though, stretch back much farther, to the time its founder, Maya Cade, was studying journalism at Howard University. There, she edited the arts section of the student newspaper, The Hilltop.

headline: What’s Going On With Vaccines for Kids Under 5?
text: When Dr. Debra Langlois learned last week that federal regulators had delayed the review of Pfizer-BioNTech’s coronavirus vaccine for children under 5, her reaction was just as visceral as any parent’s. “I was like, ‘Are you kidding me?’ Every day my daughter can’t be vaccinated, she’s at risk.”

headline: I Dug Into Whether Sanctions Will Work Against Russia
text: There are two clashing arguments about whether the threat of economic sanctions can be effective now in deterring Russian aggression in Ukraine. One is that sanctions against Russia following the 2014 invasion of Ukraine didn’t prompt any improvement in behavior, nor did sanctions promote good behavior when imposed against Cuba, Iran, Iraq, North Korea and Venezuela. So it’s unrealistic to expect sterner sanctions to work against Russia this time.

headline: Official Rules: 2022 Modern Love College Essay Contest
text: Read the official rules to the Modern Love column’s sixth college essay contest.

headline: Mikaela Shiffrin’s Alpine Career Is Far From Over
text: I first saw Mikaela Shiffrin ski when she was 14 at an Eastern championship for top junior racers culled from nine states. Shiffrin beat everyone (including my daughter) by 11 seconds in a race usually decided by tenths of a second, if not hundredths.

headline: ‘Alcarràs’ Wins Top Prize at Berlin Film Festival
text: BERLIN — The top prize at the Berlin International Film Festival, the Golden Bear for best feature film, was given on Wednesday to “Alcarràs,” a contemplative work about peach farmers in a village in northern Spain.

headline: How Are You Feeling About Returning to the Office? We Want to Hear About It.
text: Remote work has been a source of relief for some people. Going to the office often meant pressure to arrive early and stay late. It might have brought a steady stream of microaggressions. Even the most extroverted could find water cooler banter wearying. In numerous studies conducted last year, researchers found that a majority of women and people of color preferred working from home for a range of reasons. But plenty of employees have also missed the camaraderie and mentorship of in-person work.

headline: A union election at the Amazon warehouse on Staten Island is set for March.
text: Amazon and a fledgling union of workers at its Staten Island warehouse agreed to terms of an election for late March, setting the stage for two major elections at Amazon warehouses at the same time.

headline: Eric Adams Proposes a $98 Billion Budget With No Cuts for N.Y.P.D.
text: Mayor Eric Adams, who rode a tough-on-crime platform to victory in November, has spent his first few weeks in office being buffeted by a spate of violent crimes in New York City, including the killing of two police officers.

headline: U.S. and Russian warplanes flew dangerously close to each other.
text: U.S. and Russian warplanes operating in the eastern Mediterranean Sea flew dangerously close to each other in three separate incidents last weekend, including one in which the aircraft came within about five feet of each other, Pentagon officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Jurors in the Sarah Palin trial said they knew of the judge’s decision to dismiss before their verdict.
text: Several jurors in the defamation case brought by Sarah Palin against The New York Times said they found out about the judge’s decision to dismiss the case while they were still deliberating, the judge, Jed S. Rakoff, said in an order on Wednesday.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: West Doubts Russia’s Claims
text: After Russia seemed to step back from a military confrontation with Ukraine, the U.S. and NATO said on Wednesday that they were still looking for proof that President Vladimir Putin was open to a diplomatic resolution and was pulling back troops from Ukraine’s borders.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: The ‘Ham Sandwich’ Effect
text: Before Andrew Limbong went off to college, his mother cautioned him about the dire consequences he would face if he hugged a girl. Andrew grew up in a strict Christian household, and his parents are Indonesian immigrants, so they never spoke about sex at home.

headline: Regulators are looking into whether short sellers improperly influenced stock prices.
text: Some Wall Street investors have made a profession out of exposing companies with shoddy or even fraudulent operations while betting that their share prices will fall. But Justice Department officials have been looking into whether some of these activist investors, known as short sellers, may be taking their tactics too far.

headline: Against Villanova, Providence Gets a Taste of the Big Games Ahead
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — The first clue about what the Dunkin’ Donuts Center’s atmosphere would be like on Tuesday came 90 minutes before tipoff when the student sections — its inhabitants seemingly all armed with 25-ounce beer cans — were already packed.

headline: After winning medals in men’s aerial skiing, a Ukrainian and a Russian athlete embrace.
text: Oleksandr Abramenko of Ukraine took second in men’s aerial skiing on Wednesday, earning the country’s first medal of the Beijing Games.

headline: Mudslides in Brazil Kill at Least 94 People
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Firefighters and desperate residents searched for victims Wednesday after powerful mudslides and flooding swept through a mountainous region north of Rio de Janeiro, dumping a month’s worth of rain overnight and killing at least 94 people.

headline: Bulls Embrace Their Status as a Joyous Work in Progress
text: CHICAGO — About a month before training camp last fall, the Chicago Bulls began meeting up in their city, which would become a new home for most of them.

headline: Harriet S. Shapiro, Groundbreaker in Solicitor General’s Office, Dies at 93
text: Harriet S. Shapiro, the first female lawyer ever hired in the U.S. solicitor general’s office to present cases to the Supreme Court on behalf of the federal government, died on Feb. 1 in a hospice facility in Rockville, Md. She was 93.

headline: Defiant Ottawa Protesters Brace for a Clampdown
text: [Follow our live coverage of the Ottawa Protests.]

headline: Queen’s Jubilee Year Just Started, but Bad News Hasn’t Stopped for Royals
text: LONDON — In a royal family where scandal seems to rotate among its members with nearly metronomic regularity, one might have predicted that Tuesday’s news that Prince Andrew had settled a sexual abuse lawsuit against him would soon be followed by a fresh, troubling disclosure about another royal.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Love, Sharks and a Viral Cure
text: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: A former Goldman Sachs banker says the plot to loot a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund was laid out in 2012.
text: A key witness in the bribery and money-laundering trial of a former Goldman Sachs executive said the scheme to loot billions of dollars from a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund was laid out a decade ago inside the apartment of a flamboyant Asian businessman who remains on the run.

headline: Texas sues to strike down the federal mask mandate for air travelers.
text: The Republican attorney general of Texas on Wednesday sued to strike down the Biden administration’s mandate requiring travelers to wear masks at airports, on airplanes and on commuter bus and rail systems.

headline: On the Scene: New York Fashion Week
text: I’m a political photographer for The Times, but last week I tried something new: I covered fashion week for the first time.

headline: ‘We Lost Everything,’ Resident Says After Deadly Mudslides in Brazil
text: Mudslides and flooding caused by intense rainfall swept through the city of Petrópolis, located in a mountainous region north of Rio de Janeiro, destroying homes and inundating streets.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: Hong Kong’s Scary Surge
text: Hong Kong is in the thick of its worst wave yet and is facing a dangerous dilemma: It can’t live with the virus, but can’t stop it, either.

headline: Police in Ottawa Deliver Written Warning to Protesters
text: The police handed out leaflets ordering protesters in Ottawa who had been blockading the streets of the Canadian capital to leave its downtown area or face criminal charges.

headline: Russia, Winter Olympics, Fashion Week: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Canada reclaims the women’s hockey gold, dethroning the U.S.
text: All through the Beijing Games, the unchecked swagger of Canada’s women’s hockey team had been conspicuous for all to see — and to admire, fume over and fear.

headline: U.S. prime-time broadcast coverage includes medal events in Alpine skiing and women’s hockey.
text: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Wednesday with medal events in Alpine skiing and women’s hockey, as curling continues. All times are Eastern.

headline: Mikaela Shiffrin fails to finish the slalom portion of the combined event.
text: Mikaela Shiffrin’s nightmarish Beijing Olympics continued on Thursday when she tripped on a gate and toppled to the snow in the women’s combined. It was the third race she failed to finish in the last two weeks.

headline: For his last Olympics, the skier Gus Kenworthy is competing for Britain.
text: He has competed in the Winter Games twice before, but this year will look different for the freestyle skier Gus Kenworthy. He has a new team and a new Olympic event: halfpipe skiing.

headline: Defense Rests in Trial of Former Angels Employee
text: FORT WORTH — After nearly four dozen witnesses testified over the course of a week, the trial of Eric Kay over his role in the death of the Los Angeles Angels pitcher Tyler Skaggs neared its completion on Wednesday, with Kay’s lawyers resting their case. Closing arguments are scheduled for Thursday.

headline: Ryan Zinke Broke Ethics Rules as Interior Secretary, Inquiry Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Ryan Zinke, the former interior secretary, misused his position and lied to investigators about his involvement in a Montana land deal, repeatedly breaking federal ethics rules, a government watchdog said on Wednesday.

headline: Private Equity Investor Sentenced to 15 Months in College Bribery Case
text: A private equity investor who paid more than $1.2 million to secure the admission of his three children to elite universities as purported athletic recruits was sentenced on Wednesday to 15 months in prison, the longest sentence yet in the nationwide college admissions bribery case, prosecutors said.

headline: The Education Department will wipe out loans for students defrauded by DeVry University.
text: The Education Department will cancel federal student loans for at least 1,800 students who attended DeVry University, once one of the nation’s largest for-profit college chains, because it fraudulently lured in applicants for years with vastly inflated claims about their career prospects.

headline: Covid Patients May Have Increased Risk of Developing Mental Health Problems
text: Social isolation, economic stress, loss of loved ones and other struggles during the pandemic have contributed to rising mental health issues like anxiety and depression.

headline: Ukraine Tensions Spike as West Accuses Russia of Lying About Troop Withdrawal
text: KYIV, Ukraine — Tensions over Ukraine abruptly ratcheted up on Wednesday as Western officials accused Russia of lying about whether it had really begun pulling back troops from the Ukrainian border.

headline: Hugo Torres, Former Rebel Turned Political Prisoner, Dies at 73
text: Hugo Torres, a former guerrilla leader who helped spring Nicaraguan president Daniel Ortega out of jail, only to be imprisoned by Mr. Ortega himself last year, died on Friday at a hospital in Managua. He was 73.

headline: Walter Dellinger, 80, Scholar and Top Legal Aide Under Clinton, Dies
text: Walter Dellinger, a renowned scholar of constitutional law and one of the top legal figures in the Clinton administration, in which he served as head of the Office of Legal Counsel and later as acting solicitor general, died on Wednesday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 80.

headline: Kuwait Overturns Law Used to Prosecute Transgender People
text: CAIRO — Kuwait’s constitutional court overturned a law on Wednesday that authorities had used to prosecute transgender people, saying the statute violated Kuwaitis’ right to personal freedom. Activists hailed the decision as a landmark for transgender rights in the Middle East.

headline: U.C. Berkeley Says It May Have to Cut Student Admissions by Thousands
text: The University of California, Berkeley, said it might have to accept thousands fewer students than planned after a state appellate court ruled that it had to keep enrollment at 2020-21 levels, when the pandemic led to an unusually low number of students at the university.

headline: How are halfpipes made?
text: Dozens of skiers will try to dazzle a panel of judges with their aerial acrobatics in halfpipe qualifying in men’s and women’s freestyle skiing, which begins on Thursday.

headline: On Ukraine Crisis, Biden Seeks to Show His Mettle
text: America’s chaotic exit from Afghanistan last year was a made-for-TV tragedy — complete with camera-ready scenes of frantic civilians, harried U.S. Marines and helicopters hovering over an embassy roof.

headline: Prosecutors Show Voluminous Evidence of Racism by Arbery Murderers
text: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — Federal prosecutors in the hate crimes trial of Ahmaud Arbery’s three murderers on Wednesday presented the jury with voluminous digital evidence of racism, as the government continued to build its case that the defendants, who are white, chased Mr. Arbery through their South Georgia neighborhood because he was Black.

headline: Effort to Weaken Press Protections Isn’t Likely to End With Palin Case
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Who’s to Blame for Sneaky Partisan Line-Drawing?
text: Pop quiz: When lawmakers meet to study the 2020 census results and redraw their congressional and state legislative districts, their overriding goal is generally:

headline: Philadelphia drops its vaccine mandate for indoor dining.
text: Philadelphia is joining a growing list of cities that will no longer require proof of vaccination to enter places that serve food or drink.

headline: Covid patients may have increased risk of developing mental health problems.
text: Social isolation, economic stress, loss of loved ones and other struggles during the pandemic have contributed to rising mental health issues like anxiety and depression.

headline: Corrections: Feb. 17, 2022
text: An article on Wednesday about challenges faced by U.S. intelligence agencies in deciphering the moves of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia described incorrectly John Sipher’s role with the C.I.A. in Moscow. He served there as a C.I.A. officer, not as the station chief.

headline: In Medieval Europe, a Pandemic Changed Work Forever. Can It Happen Again?
text: In the wake of a devastating pandemic, millions of people are dead and many more have had their lives upended. Many of those who survive, worn down by a sense of futility in their work and by the impassable gap between the wealthy and everyone else, refuse to return to their old jobs or quit en masse. Tired of being overworked and underpaid, they feel they deserve a better life.

headline: For Trump, a Perilous Exclamation Point to Years of Wealth Inflation
text: On Tuesday evening, former President Donald J. Trump, rattled by news that his longtime accountants had declared that years of his financial statements were not reliable, issued a statement of self-defense with new claims about his wealth.

headline: Justice Department Sues Missouri Over Expansive Gun-Rights Law
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department sued Missouri on Wednesday over the state’s far-reaching gun law, which discourages local officials from enforcing federal firearms measures.

headline: Eileen Gu gets the highest score at freeski halfpipe, taking aim at a third medal.
text: Eileen Gu, already with two Olympic medals in Beijing, moved her ambitions to the freeski halfpipe on Thursday.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Oh, You Want a Garage Door?
text: “It used to take us 20 weeks to build a house. And now it takes us 20 weeks to get a set of garage doors.”

headline: It’s Berry Tasty!
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Thursday puzzles are my favorites because of their intrinsic element of surprise, that extra layer of mystery to dig into. Today’s Aaron M. Rosenberg special, his first crossword for The New York Times, has a cherry of narrative whimsy on top. There’s a scientist with a new invention to show off, and we are all guests at a party, or guinea pigs, if you will. We can mix and mingle and fill in the blanks; we can dine and we will leave, if not sated then quite satisfied.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Tensions over Ukraine abruptly ratcheted up on Wednesday as Western officials accused Russia of lying about whether it had really begun pulling back troops from the Ukrainian border.

headline: After an Unexpected Rise, Hochul Cements Her Front-Runner Status
text: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at how Gov. Kathy Hochul assembled a campaign juggernaut. We’ll also look at the difficulties facing would-be small business owners who dream of becoming marijuana retailers in New Jersey.

headline: The U.S. overnight broadcast coverage includes figure skating and hockey.
text: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Thursday with figure skating and hockey. All times are Eastern.

headline: Sandra Naeslund of Sweden takes the gold in the ski cross final.
text: For all of its high speed and spills, Alpine skiing is, in its own way, a controlled, stately affair. After all, each skier gets a fair chance to race down the mountain, uninterrupted and unmolested.

headline: The U.S. men’s curling team loses to Britain and fails to defend its gold medal.
text: The U.S. men’s curling team’s bid for a second gold medal ended on Thursday after an 8-4 loss in the semifinal to Britain.

headline: No Covid cases were detected on Wednesday, a first for the Games.
text: With nearly 70,000 people inside Beijing’s “closed loop” taking Covid tests every day, not a single case was detected on Wednesday, the first day of the Games that was entirely free of new cases.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Critiques Trump’s Latest Rambling Statement
text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: vice versa
text: The term vice versa has appeared in 204 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 15 in “Why Don’t We Have a Covid Vaccine for Pets?” by Emily Anthes:

headline: F.A.A. Administrator Steve Dickson Will Resign Next Month
text: WASHINGTON — Steve Dickson, the administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, will resign at the end of next month, the agency said on Wednesday night.

headline: Julia Fox, Eric Adams and the Return of the Suit
text: It’s been a while since a New York Fashion Week show was an hour late and almost no one cared.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
text: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Kamila Valieva misses out on a medal, capping a stunning end to her time in Beijing.
text: Kamila Valieva, Russia’s figure skating prima ballerina, uncharacteristically faltered in the women’s individual event on Thursday, stumbling and falling several times and tumbling to fourth place in an event she had widely been expected to dominate.

headline: France Announces Troop Withdrawal From Mali After 9-Year Campaign
text: PARIS — France announced on Thursday that it would pull out its troops from the West African nation of Mali, bringing to a bitter end a nine-year military mission that has failed to quash a terrorist threat in the increasingly unstable region and has undermined France’s once dominant standing in many of its former African colonies.

headline: Looking Straight at the Struggles of Old Age
text: PARIS — There is something piercing, almost brutal, about watching someone struggle to walk, eat or even sit down. When faced with the physical decline that often comes with old age, many of us instinctively avert our eyes. In Paris, however, two theater artists are forcing audiences to look.

headline: The Best-Seller List Is a Smorgasbord
text: ORIGINAL KIN In the vibrant potluck that is the best-seller list, occasionally we find a book that stands out among the usual bowls of chili, trays of baked ziti and platters of Rice Krispie treats. This week the dish that isn’t quite like the others — thriller, mystery, memoir or biography, and so forth — is Jennifer Raff’s “Origin,” which our reviewer described as a “masterly retelling of the story of how, and when, people reached the Americas.” Raff, an anthropological geneticist at the University of Kansas, writes in her introduction, “Looking at the genetic evidence, we will examine the ways in which DNA has challenged and changed our understanding of Native American history, with a special focus on the events that are only indirectly understandable with the archaeological record.” Her approach will be accessible to the pickiest readers, layering personal anecdotes with a visit to a gene-sequencing lab, heavy on compassion and light on jargon. A Goodreads reviewer put it like this about Raff: “As a young mother she can’t help but impart some poignancy in her accounts of those burial sites where toddlers are interred. In doing so she highlights — as she does throughout the book — the humanity of the person whose remains are the subject of research.” “Origin” is Raff’s first book, and it lands on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 8.

headline: A Man in a Cafe Asked Julie Otsuka What She Was Reading. They Dated for Two Years.
text: “An everyday pickup line, but it worked,” says the novelist Julie Otsuka, whose new book is “The Swimmers.” “I haven’t been in touch with him since, but I return to ‘The Lover’ every now and again, and never fail to fall under its spell.”

headline: Their Windowless Living Room Wasn’t Cutting It in the Pandemic, but Could They Afford More in Manhattan?
text: When their home suddenly became their office, a couple decided it was time to ditch their dark Chelsea rental and seek more space. Which option would you choose?

headline: Do You Support Affirmative Action in College Admissions?
text: The Supreme Court has agreed to hear two cases, one involving Harvard and the other the University of North Carolina, that could reshape college admissions. Both schools are being accused of race-based discrimination in their admission practices. In the coming year, the court will examine whether it’s lawful for college admissions offices to consider a student’s race.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Joint Birthday
text: Colin writes: My partner, Emily, and I share the same birthday. This year, I turn 29, and she turns 30. Emily wants a joint celebration. I say Emily’s birthday is a much bigger deal than mine: There should be a big party for her and smaller, separate event for me. Who’s right?

headline: Poem: Kingdom
text: Joyelle McSweeney’s book explores the ecstasy of impending childbirth and the fissure of joy when the baby is born with a birth defect, lives for 13 days and dies. “Kingdom” is a poem written after the baby’s death. It’s a spiteful elegy against the persistent onslaught of spring and of the indifference of the world surrounding a death. This poem’s brilliance (and wounds) register through language’s sonic playfulness, as if to say that language is the only way to clap back at grief. The speaker’s bold agency is empowering — even the last line is an unexpected imperative.Selected by Victoria Chang

headline: Our Allies Deserve Better Than Starvation and a Life on the Run
text: On Aug. 10, 2021, days before the collapse of Afghanistan’s government, Fawad Khan Safi arrived in the United States to begin his new life.

headline: Is Tech’s Love Affair With Miami About Taxes, or Something Else?
text: Keith Rabois minted his wealth with Elon Musk, Peter Thiel and other members of the so-called “PayPal Mafia.” Now, though, he’s moved to Miami and become one of the city’s biggest hype men. He believes Florida — which has already seen an influx of tech bros, venture capital investments and cryptocurrency plays during the pandemic — offers a better home to tech than California can, largely because of the politics. He tells Kara Swisher: “The mayor of Miami, the governor of Florida treat citizens like customers. ‘What can we offer you? How can we help?’ That’s their goal, and that’s how they frame everything.”

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘How Bad Is the Western Drought? Worst in 12 Centuries, Study Finds.’
text: Featured Article: “How Bad Is the Western Drought? Worst in 12 Centuries, Study Finds.” by Henry Fountain

headline: Where You Still Need to Wear a Mask in New York City
text: New York is set to issue new rollbacks of its coronavirus-related safety precautions in the coming weeks, joining other parts of the country in easing masking and vaccination policies as the Omicron surge subsides.

headline: Do You Know Who That Worker You Just Hired Really Is?
text: It was as if a “Seinfeld” plot met John le Carré.

headline: A Parasitic Wasp Unmasked: One Species Is Actually 16 Species
text: The tiny, iridescent Ormyrus labotus always seemed suspicious for a parasitoid wasp. It wasn’t the wasp’s striking beauty — wasps can be conventionally attractive, too — but its life strategy. Parasitoid wasps lay their eggs on or inside other insects and arthropods, and the larvae eat their way out when they hatch. Each parasitoid wasp species tends to prefer one or a few hosts. But Ormyrus labotus had been observed laying its eggs in more than 65 different species of insects — far more than one or a few.

headline: Do Today’s Unions Have a Fighting Chance Against Corporate America?
text: In 1996, Manuel Miranda, a second-generation Filipino American from Kent, Wash., graduated from Evergreen State College. He had majored in literature and got a job in Seattle, taking care of people with cerebral palsy for $9 an hour. The city was “post-grunge” but being transformed by tech, Miranda told me. There was a lot of excitement about Amazon, the online bookseller.

headline: Covering the U.S. During the Pandemic
text: It has been nearly two years since the first Covid cases were reported in the United States. Throughout the coronavirus pandemic, the National desk has been covering the immense changes occurring in every part of the country. Reporters on the desk, stationed across the nation, are continuously adapting to major events while simultaneously dealing with the risks of Covid-19 themselves. Below, some of those reporters share a few of the ways they have adapted to this new reality — and what they’ve learned along the way.

headline: The Moral Danger of Declaring the Pandemic Over Too Soon
text: The early 1990s were in many ways the most terrible of those first years of the AIDS epidemic in America. Research on the disease was in high gear, but drug after drug failed to stop H.I.V. Funerals for friends and family in their 20s, 30s, 40s and 50s continued unabated, and many of us at risk for getting sick had given up hope of a normal life. My friends and I, most of us just a few years out of college, lived in the moment because we weren’t sure of how much time we had left.

headline: His Conducting Wasn’t Always Pleasant. But It Was the Truth.
text: Read the reviews that the German conductor Michael Gielen received during his career, and you find a running theme.

headline: Biden Keeps Blaming the Supply Chain for Inflation. That’s Dishonest.
text: In an interview with Lester Holt of NBC last week, President Biden hewed closely to his talking points on inflation, which over the past 12 months has risen at its fastest rate in 40 years. “The reason for the inflation is the supply chains were cut off,” he insisted, as he has done several times before.

headline: Sam Waterston Is Still the Face of ‘Law & Order’
text: “Law & Order” premiered on NBC in 1990. A procedural that was really two procedurals conjoined, the first half of each episode focused on the investigation of a crime, the second on the prosecution of the accused. Among the original cast members was Michael Moriarty, who played an assistant district attorney. During the fourth season, under clouded circumstances, Moriarty left.

headline: Sarah Polley Is OK With Oversharing
text: It’s been more than six years since Sarah Polley was struck on the head by a fire extinguisher, one that was unwisely hung over a lost-and-found box at her local community center, leaving her with a debilitating concussion.

headline: Vulnerable to the Virus, High-Risk Americans Feel Pain as the U.S. Moves On
text: Denisse Takes’s world is very small these days. She makes a living by producing songs from her living room, plays “Animal Crossing” online with friends and leaves her home in Burbank, Calif., only occasionally to walk her dog.

headline: The World Needs What Intel Makes. Can It Make a Comeback?
text: Patrick Gelsinger was 18 years old and four months into an entry-level job at Intel when he heard a pivotal sermon at a Silicon Valley church in February 1980. There, a minister quoted Jesus from the Book of Revelation.

headline: Can an Old Skier Learn New Tricks?
text: I hurt.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
text: Something wonderful is in the air.

headline: The $1.7 Billion Student Loan Deal That Was Too Good to Be True
text: After years of struggling to make payments that hardly put a dent in the loans she took out to attend a now defunct arts school, Victoria Linssen saw a glimmer of hope. A deal last month between 39 states and Navient, a student lending giant accused of unfairly ensnaring borrowers like her, would wipe away $1.7 billion in private student loans.

headline: A Child’s TikTok Stardom Opens Doors. Then a Gunman Arrives.
text: NAPLES, Fla. — Ava Majury downloaded TikTok when she was 13, and at the height of the pandemic lockdowns a year later had more than a million followers. Her fans, nearly three-quarters of them male, watched her lip-sync and dance to trending music on an account with the profile message, “Hey, I love you!!”

headline: Babies Have Entered the Chat
text: Planning around naps, shelling out for nannies or yelling into the void — parents working from home all have ways of coping with the daily mayhem. For these intimate portraits — of anxiety, frustration and also unbridled joy — we visited the New York homes of working parents and photographed them during real video meetings at their jobs, occasionally donning noise-canceling headphones to preserve their offices’ privacy. All photos capture the natural reactions of both parent and child over the course of the meetings. (No babies were made to cry.)

headline: South Korea, a Virus Success Story, Now Finds Its Model Unsustainable
text: SEOUL — For the past two years, South Korea waged a successful battle against Covid-19 with a so-called three-T strategy: it ramped up lab “tests” to ferret out infections, it “traced” contacts using modern technology, and it “treated” patients by keeping them in isolation, where they were monitored by the government.

headline: Vocabulary in Context: Halftime Show
text: Test your vocabulary and reading comprehension with this quiz based on the Times article "Rap Takes Over Super Bowl Halftime, Balancing Celebration and Protest."

headline: ‘I live in a different world’: Here’s how high-risk Americans feel as the U.S. moves on.
text: Since March 2020, millions of people in the United States with weakened immune systems, disabilities or illnesses that make them especially vulnerable to the coronavirus have been sequestering at home, keeping their children out of school and skipping medical care rather than risk exposure to the virus. And they have seethed over talk from politicians and public health experts that they perceive as minimizing the value of their lives.

headline: Why U.S. Soldiers Won’t Come to Ukraine’s Rescue
text: In the last 48 hours, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his officials say they have ordered back a good number of troops who were engaged in military exercises on the border with Ukraine. But there hasn’t been a lot of change on the ground.

headline: A Jeff Koons Paint Job on a BMW Canvas
text: In the late 2000s, when the artist Jeff Koons was asked to design a BMW Art Car, he considered three concepts. “I made Plan A, Plan B and Plan C,” Mr. Koons said.

headline: ‘A whistling sound, then an explosion’: Shelling hits a kindergarten in Ukraine.
text: STANYTSIA LUHANSKA, Ukraine — The fighting between Russian-backed separatists and Ukrainian government forces has been flaring for eight years. Daily skirmishes, mostly low-level, had become routine.

headline: Shiffrin’s Olympics End as They Began, With a Sudden Fall and a Frank Review
text: YANQING, China — For Mikaela Shiffrin, the most unexpected of Olympic journeys culminated just as it began: with one more crash, one more disqualification, one more frank assessment of a race she had lost instead of one she had won.

headline: San Francisco ousters
text: Elections to the San Francisco Board of Education are not normally national bellwethers. The city is a proud symbol of liberalism, not a swing district, and school-board elections — as Thomas Fuller, The Times’s San Francisco bureau chief, notes — “have for decades been obscure sideshows to the more high-profile political contests.”

headline: Russia claims team figure skating medals ‘are not subject to revision.’
text: See our coverage of the closing ceremony of the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics here.

headline: Karen Chen of the U.S. has another bumpy performance.
text: Karen Chen, the 2017 U.S. national champion, had been waiting to unveil her new costume in the free skate at this Olympics, and it is stunning!

headline: ‘A Banquet’ Review: Starving for a Higher Purpose
text: When it gets down to it, demonic haunting bears striking similarities to divine possession. So who gets canonized and who receives an exorcism? “A Banquet,” the first feature film from the director Ruth Paxton, smartly asks audiences to consider the overlaps between reality and fantasy, psychosis and evangelism.

headline: ‘Ted K’ Review: An Eerie Descent
text: Shot largely in the secluded mountains outside Lincoln, Mont., where the real Theodore J. Kaczynski lived before his arrest by the F.B.I. in 1996, “Ted K” is a blinkered portrait of the infamous domestic terrorist known as the Unabomber.

headline: ‘Strawberry Mansion’ Review: Adventures in Slumberland
text: “Strawberry Mansion,” a soulful sci-fi oddity from Albert Birney and Kentucker Audley, is a dollhouse constructed on a fault line. Birney and Audley, who both directed and edited the film, evoke the disarray of dream logic: The sets shift, the sound effects heighten and the props grow and shrink. Initially, the style is stifling, giving the sense that the wallpaper might matter more than the plot. One room is painted solid pink, with matching pink house plants and a pink broom. Another room houses a machine covered in incomprehensible widgets and tubes, plus a turtle named Sugar Baby. But oh, how the two filmmakers enjoy knocking down the walls of their own creation. This is a movie about letting the mind roam.

headline: ‘Dog’ Review: Man and Beast Hit the Road
text: Road comedies that pair an animal and a movie star are a minor genre unto themselves. The best examples, in my opinion, involve Clint Eastwood and an orangutan named Clyde, though the recent one with Eastwood and a rooster wasn’t bad. Channing Tatum is a different kind of screen presence — sweeter, chattier, bulkier — and in “Dog,” which he directed with Reid Carolin, he amiably shares the screen with (spoiler alert!) a dog.

headline: ‘Inspector Ike’ Review: A Murder Mystery Send-Up, ’70s-TV style
text: Cinephiles tend to associate American microbudget filmmaking with raw, edgy earnestness, but some aspirational indies are very much into knowingly silly comedy — see, for instance, the 2017 short “Snowy Bing Bongs Across the North Star Combat Zone.”

headline: ‘Uncharted’ Review: Steal, Fight, Repeat
text: At least give Sony credit for recycling. That is the best that can be said for its nitwit treasure-hunt movie “Uncharted,” an amalgam of clichés that were already past their sell-by date when Nicolas Cage plundered the box office in Disney’s “National Treasure” series. Now, it is Tom Holland’s turn to cash in with a musty story about ancient loot, old maps, lost ships, invisible ink and a wealthy scoundrel with disposable minions. But while he’s following in Cage’s inimitable footsteps, Holland also seems in training to become Tom Cruise 2.0.

headline: ‘Pursuit’ Review: An Action Thriller Destined for the Bargain Bin
text: Grenades play a pivotal role in “Pursuit,” starring John Cusack and Emile Hirsch as estranged father and son. If the prospect of those actors intrigues you, pull the pin on your curiosity. In a previous era, this action thriller, directed by Brian Skiba, would have gone from postproduction directly into a bargain bin at a rundown video emporium on a dark alley where rats scurried.

headline: The Queer Indigenous Artists Reclaiming a Fluid Sense of Gender
text: THE PHOTOGRAPH FRAMES what appears to be a female figure, naked and glossed with oil, against a backdrop of pale rose brown, just a shade darker than the model’s skin. Long, dark hair cascades over the breasts and, where the viewer might expect the genitalia to be, the model grips the great rack of a caribou, the skull cupped like a codpiece and the antlers jutting out, beams spread nearly four feet wide and reaching in height from mid-thigh to the tip of the model’s nose, with 15 points on each side.

headline: The ‘kiss and cry’ booth is really a hard bench.
text: The bench in the much-discussed “kiss and cry” area does not look very comfortable — a hard, padless block. Perhaps that’s fitting, since it’s not a very comfortable moment for skaters awaiting their judgment.

headline: Half of the cars arriving at dealers are already sold, AutoNation says.
text: The tight supplies of new and used cars that have damped auto sales and pushed prices higher have not eased and are likely to linger well into this year, according to AutoNation, the country’s largest automotive retailer.

headline: Mariah Bell has a fall-free, joy-filled performance.
text: Mariah Bell had a wide smile before her skate, a sign that she was actually enjoying herself. And after her soulful routine to “Hallelujah,” she has even more reason to smile.

headline: Florida Girl Arrested Over Threats She Didn’t Make Sues Her School
text: The family of a Florida girl who was held in a juvenile-detention center for 11 days after a classmate impersonated her on social media to make threats against their school has filed a lawsuit against the school and Instagram for their roles in the episode.

headline: As Russian Wins Mount, So Does the Scrutiny
text: BEIJING — Inside the Olympic bubble, everybody just calls them the Russians.

headline: Waiting for Bing Dwen Dwen
text: A week into the Winter Games, I went to the flagship store in downtown Beijing that sells Olympics merchandise — and joined the end of a long line.

headline: Child Safety Is the New Tech Battleground
text: Two senators from opposite sides of the aisle introduced sweeping legislation yesterday that would require online platforms to help parents better control their children’s online experience. The Kids Online Safety Act, which comes after months of news reports and Congressional hearings on social media’s impact on children’s mental health and safety, is lawmakers’ latest bid to limit the power of internet giants.

headline: A Ring That Encapsulates Chanel No. 5 in Gem Form
text: When Gabrielle “Coco” Chanel decided in 1920 to branch out from fashion to fragrance, she chose the fifth sample presented by her team of noses, a mélange of ylang-ylang from Madagascar, May rose and piquant jasmine grown in the southern French commune of Grasse. The golden color of Chanel No. 5, which could be seen through the simple square-corner glass bottle — designed to contrast with the ornate cut crystal vessels made by Lalique and Baccarat at the time — was almost as important as its bouquet. That warm yellow hue and the dizzying waft of sillage in its wake were among the things that inspired Patrice Leguéreau, who directs the house’s fine jewelry studio, to render the radically modern scent in gem form. Resembling a flower exploding into bloom with a five-carat emerald-cut diamond as its luminous pistil and stamen, surrounded by a cascade of yellow sapphires and orange spessartite garnets, this captivating ring manages the impossible: turning the fleeting frisson of fragrance into an eternal object of desire. Chanel High Jewelry Golden Sillage ring, price on request, (800) 550-0005.

headline: Given a Chance at a Mediocre Season, the Celtics Said: We’ll Pass
text: BOSTON — Ime Udoka has been emphasizing ball movement since the day the Celtics hired him as their coach. At his introductory news conference last June, Udoka apologized to Brad Stevens, his predecessor and the team’s newly appointed president of basketball operations, as a way of softening the blow before he pointed out that the Celtics had ranked near the bottom of the league in assists last season.

headline: ‘Downfall: The Case Against Boeing’ Review: Behind Two Fatal Crashes
text: Regardless of any changes that Boeing made to the 737 Max, regardless of the clearance the revised plane received from the Federal Aviation Administration in late 2020, “Downfall: The Case Against Boeing” leaves the impression that its entire existence is a mistake: that it was cobbled together for the wrong reasons, to boost short-term stock gains and to avoid the time and costs of engineering a new, non-737 plane.

headline: Explaining the Los Angeles Mayor’s Race
text: Late last week, after months of speculation and hours before the Saturday deadline, the billionaire developer Rick Caruso jumped into the race to become mayor of Los Angeles.

headline: Walmart profits grow as consumers continue to spend.
text: Walmart navigated rising inflation and fickle consumer confidence in its fourth quarter, as sales rose and profit increased, beating analysts’ expectations.

headline: Must I Keep Reminding My Adult Son About Family Birthdays?
text: I have three grown sons, all married with children. The wives of the older two meticulously observe every family birthday and milestone event with cards and gifts. My youngest son didn’t marry until his mid-30s. While single, he often neglected these occasions. I would remind him about them, particularly for his young nieces and nephews, but he was spotty about acknowledging them. And I heard frequently from my daughters-in-law about hurt feelings. Now that he’s married, I had hoped his wife would take up the cause of cards and gifts for family unity. She hasn’t. And my other daughters-in-law still let me know about every omission. What more should I do?

headline: An Art-Filled Hotel Inside a Former Wall Street Trading Hub
text: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: A Russian Star Falls and Another Rises in a Blur of Jumps, Tumbles and Tears
text: BEIJING — Kamila Valieva, the Russian figure skating star at the center of a doping scandal, showed up at the Olympic rink on Thursday night facing a single, heavy expectation, especially heavy for a 15-year-old who has soared to the top of her sport in a quick four months, only to fall from it while the world was watching.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s properties are in Carroll Gardens, Battery Park City and Greenwich Village.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: This week’s properties are a three-bedroom house in White Plains, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in Hopewell, N.J.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: After 30 Years of Peace, Ukraine Crisis Shakes Europeans
text: BRUSSELS — Ulrike Franke is a self-confessed German millennial, a defense analyst who worries about her generation’s allergy to the military, especially as it moves into positions of power.

headline: Want a Profitable Short-Term Rental? Try These Spots.
text: For those fortunate enough to own an Airbnb or Vrbo property, 2021 was a stellar year. According to a new analysis by AirDNA, an unaffiliated company that collects and analyzes data from short-term rental listings, 62 percent of such properties were occupied at any given time in 2021 — up 5 percent from 2020 and 10 percent from 2019. And thanks to the increased demand, landlords were able to charge higher rates, earning them an average of 39 percent more annually than before the pandemic.

headline: Sell-off of stocks deepens as Ukraine adds to investors’ worries.
text: Stocks slid on Thursday, extending a volatile stretch of trading brought on by uncertainty about inflation, rising interest rates and the potential for war in Europe.

headline: It’s Telfar’s World. We’re Just Living in It.
text: For almost a decade, the unofficial honor of closing New York Fashion Week — of having the last word — went to Marc Jacobs, the favored son of the city, who had gone to Paris and conquered, showing the world that American designers could hold their own with the French.

headline: Is It Funny for the Jews?
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Latest on Vaccines for Kids Under 5
text: A series of events over the last few weeks have made it confusing and difficult for parents to know when a Covid vaccine might be available to protect their children.

headline: 30 years of post-Cold War peace in Europe is being shattered by the Ukraine crisis.
text: BRUSSELS — Ulrike Franke is a self-confessed German millennial, a defense analyst who worries about her generation’s allergy to the military, especially as it moves into positions of power.

headline: ‘Top of the Heap’: Is It Blaxploitation? Avant-Garde? Afrofuturism? All Three.
text: The tale of a tightly wound Black police officer whose identity crisis leads to an action-packed nervous breakdown, “Top of the Heap” makes a statement — not least in that its writer-director, Christopher St. John, is also the star.

headline: A City Ballet Star Bids Farewell to the ‘Crazy Ballerina Life’
text: New York City Ballet’s fall season came and went, and if Teresa Reichlen was being honest with herself, she wasn’t feeling it. This was concerning. What kind of dancer wasn’t itching to perform after 18 months off the stage?

text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: ‘Severance’ Review: That Makes Two of You
text: Two years into a pandemic, you would be forgiven for believing that the science-fiction aspect of Apple TV+’s “Severance” is that it involves people working side by side in an office.

headline: The U.S. adds WeChat and AliExpress to a list of notorious piracy markets.
text: The Biden administration on Thursday added WeChat’s e-commerce ecosystem and AliExpress, an e-commerce site owned by Alibaba, to an annual list of markets that the United States says engage in counterfeiting and copyright violations.

headline: Tears and sobs, and not just from Kamila Valieva, follow her crushing Olympic end.
text: Kamila Valieva, the Russian star at the center of a doping scandal, knew immediately it had all gone wrong.

headline: Rokia Koné, From Mali, Sings for the World. Especially Women.
text: African musicians don’t need outside help. Lately, Nigerian Afrobeats, South African amapiano and other sleek, high-tech, thoroughly danceable styles have reached listeners worldwide without Western mediators. But the proof of a collaboration is in its sound, not its pedigree, and the album “Bamanan” is a transcontinental alliance that finds its own synergy.

headline: What Was Stonehenge For? The Answer Might Be Simpler Than You Thought.
text: LONDON — In 2003, the Canadian gynecologist Anthony M. Perks came up with an anatomical explanation for Stonehenge, the prehistoric monument in England whose precise purpose is a mystery.

headline: A Look Inside the Chicken Industry
text: To the Editor:

headline: How Kamila Valieva Fell to Fourth as Russian Teammate Took Gold
text: In women’s figure skating, see the moves that won Anna Shcherbakova Olympic gold as Kamila Valieva, her Russian teammate caught up in a doping scandal, faltered.

headline: Rosalie Kunoth-Monks, Champion of Indigenous Peoples, Dies at 85
text: Rosalie Kunoth-Monks, who as a teenager was believed to be the first female Indigenous person to star in a feature film in Australia, and who later became an Aboriginal rights activist, died on Jan. 26 in Alice Springs, in Australia’s Northern Territory. She was 85 and had been living in Utopia, an Aboriginal homeland.

headline: Belarusian leader says exercises with Russia are not a sign of an imminent invasion of Ukraine.
text: OSIPOVICHI, Belarus — Mocking the United States for spending billions on intelligence agencies that he said had wrongly predicted an attack on Ukraine, the autocratic leader of Belarus, Russia’s western neighbor and closest ally, said Thursday that joint military exercises now underway between the countries did not presage an invasion — at least not now.

headline: Handshakes and hugs have some Canadians questioning law enforcement’s soft touch with the protests.
text: Police in Ottawa are poised for a crackdown on the protests that have immobilized Canada’s capital, but after three weeks of scant enforcement, images of police officers fraternizing with protesters have some Canadians questioning the gentle treatment of the demonstrations.

headline: Leslie Parnas, Celebrated Cellist and Musical Diplomat, Dies at 90
text: Leslie Parnas, a renowned cellist and teacher whose second-place award at the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow at the height of the Cold War helped propel him to a storied career, died on Feb. 1 at a rehabilitation facility in Venice, Fla. He was 90.

headline: Australia gives a green light to Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine for children aged 6 to 11.
text: Australia’s medicines regulator granted provisional approval on Wednesday to Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine in children aged 6 to 11. It is the first time a national regulator has approved the vaccine for children younger than 12.

headline: First Arabic Film by Netflix Stirs Fierce Morality Debate
text: CAIRO — In one of the opening scenes, a Lebanese mother confronts her 17-year-old daughter after discovering two condoms in her purse. Minutes later, an Egyptian wife sneakily slips off her underwear just before leaving for dinner with her husband.

headline: How Many of Us Just Fake Our Confidence and Calm?
text: It happens almost every day: A friend, an acquaintance or a complete stranger confides in me about a past struggle that only a few people in his or her life are privy to, about physical pain or emotional turmoil that almost nobody sees.

headline: Why Podcasts Are Becoming Netflix
text: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.

headline: Bobsleds Come Down Fast. This Is How They Go Back Up.
